item.content:encoded:
SYMPOSIUM

The symposium is called “Vision 2050”, where students will have to discuss a case study presented to them prior to the day of the event to come up with innovate solutions to address the case studies and finally present them during the event.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

The Vision 2050 Symposium is an event designed for students to analyze a case study they are provided with and present it in a public platform with innovative solutions that they had come up with.
The United Nations has been significant body working on the challenges facing the world today, from climate change to infectious diseases, which are not localized. The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), otherwise known as the Global Goals, are a universal call to action to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure that all people enjoy peace and prosperity. These 17 Goals build on the successes of the Millennium Development Goals while including new areas such as climate change, economic discrimination, innovation, sustainable consumption, peace and justice, among other priorities. The goals are interconnected and are often the key to success when tackling issues more commonly associated with another.
This allows participants to:
  • Develop their problem-solving skills
  • Enhance their presentation skills
  • Learn more about current issues

Event Guidelines:

  • Participants will be provided with the case studies prior to the competition.
  • The medium of the presentation can be anything eg. a powerpoint presentation or/and a model.
  • Students can use small banners or charts to mention name and case study topic to display during the symposium.
  • A time duration of a maximum of 8 mins will be allotted to each team.

Registration details

  • Participate in TEAMS of 3 or 4, Total of 6 teams
  • Class-7-9th
  • Total registrations: 24

Judgment Criteria

  • Innovation
  • Ability to solve the problem
  • Medium of instruction
  • Environmental friendliness of the solution
  • Sustainability of the solution

Case studies:

In industrial regions of southern China, water pollution is an increasingly serious problem. According to the Nanfang Daily, 12.62 billion tons of polluted materials and 8.3 billion tons of wastewater were discharged into the waters off Guangdong in 2007—up 60 percent from five years ago. Perhaps most distressing, according to Guangdong officials, more than 40 percent of the province’s rural people do not have access to safe drinking water. In southern China, the apparel and textile industry’s discharge of wastewater containing reactive dyes is a serious environmental challenge contributing to the problem of polluted water. The load is characterized by high colour content, with suspended solids, salts, nutrients, and toxic substances such as heavy metals and chlorinated organic compounds that pose significant risks to human health, including exposure to constituents such as chloride, nitrate, nitrite, and sulfate. In addition, the effluents discharged lead to serious pollution of surface water sources and groundwater, inhibiting biological processes and the productivity of rivers and streams. Think upon these lines, develop a solution to manage the improper waste disposal into the water bodies.
  1. Lafarge uses biomass waste as alternative fuel in its Malaysia plants, allowing it to reduce fossil fuel consumption and associated CO2 emissions. The waste comes from the agricultural, timber, furniture and construction sectors in both Malaysia and neighbouring Singapore. We work with a number of waste-treatment companies that source the untreated biomass waste. We have installed the necessary equipment at our cement plants to receive and store this waste and feed it into our cement kilns as a substitute fuel for coal. The biomass waste generated from the agricultural, timber, furniture and construction sectors poses a disposal problem for the industries concerned and in the past was commonly land-filled or burned with no energy recovery. Using this waste as alternative fuel, the, therefore, provides a disposal solution while also allowing us to reduce the amount of coal – all of which has to be imported – that we burn in our cement kilns. Discuss.
     
  2. Located in an area of extreme water scarcity, Lafarge’s Fuhais cement plant in Jordan introduced rainwater harvesting and implemented a water recycling system to reduce its use of freshwater. The aim was to reduce its water withdrawal from the local domestic network.

  3. The plant installed pools dedicated to rainwater collection and run-off from cleaning operations. Water from these pools is pumped through pipes to a water treatment plant and stored afterwards in industrial tanks, before being used by the plant. This closed-loop system has allowed a significant reduction in freshwater consumption and also ensures that no water is discharged outside the plant. Think about the idea of how effectively Rain -Water Harvesting Technique can be put to good use.

  4. The Retznei cement plant in the scenic Styria region of southern Austria produces 500,000 metric tons of cement per year. To reduce production costs, Lafarge Perlmooser decided to increase the proportion of alternative fuels burned by the plant, in this case by using waste plastics. This solution also delivers environmental benefits, such as reduction of global CO2 emissions by the reservation of fossil resources. However, plastics contain significant quantities of chlorine (mainly from residual table salt in food packaging), which is detrimental to the operation of the kiln. Lafarge Perlmooser decided to install a system to extract chlorinated particulates. Hot gas extracted from the furnace is recovered and cooled by addition of air. The chlorinated particulates are then captured in a bag filter and used as a cement admixture. In addition to its proven effectiveness, this solution has the advantage of low capital and maintenance costs. How can plastics be an alternative source of energy?

  5. Pollution of air, water and soil require millions of years to recoup. Industry and motor vehicle exhaust arise number one pollutants. Heavy metals, nitrates and plastic are toxins responsible for pollution. The epic historical example, The Taj Mahal has a witnessed a gradual decline in material quality and damage due to atmospheric pollution. How can air pollution be curbed and the situation be improved?

  6. Climate changes like global warming are the result of human practices like emission of greenhouse gases. Global warming leads to rising temperatures of the oceans and the earth’s surface causing melting of polar ice caps, rise in sea levels and also unnatural patterns of precipitation such as flash floods, excessive snow or desertification. How to tackle the issue of Rising Global Temperatures?

  7. Overpopulation: The population of the planet is reaching unsustainable levels as it faces a  shortage of resources like water, fuel and food. The population explosion in less developed and developing countries is straining the already scarce resources. Intensive agriculture practices produce food and environment damages through use of chemical fertilizer, pesticides and insecticides. Overpopulation is one of the crucial current environmental problems. Think about ways to solve this problem.
  8. Natural resource depletion is another crucial current environmental problem. Fossil fuel consumption results in the mission of Greenhouse gases, which is responsible for global warming and climate change. Globally, people are making efforts to shift to renewable sources of energy like solar, wind, biogas and geothermal energy. The cost of installing the infrastructure and maintaining these sources has plummeted in the recent years. How can tap solar energy an efficient solution? Comment.
  9. The over-consumption of resources and creation of plastics are creating a global crisis of waste disposal. Developed countries are notorious for producing an excessive amount of waste or garbage and dumping their waste in the oceans and, less developed countries. Nuclear waste disposal has tremendous health hazards associated with it. Plastic, fast food, packaging and cheap electronic wastes threaten the well-being of humans. Waste disposal is one of urgent current environmental problem. Discuss the concept of Reduce, use and Recycle.
  10. Loss of Biodiversity: Human activity is leading to the extinction of species and habitats and loss of biodiversity. Ecosystems, which took millions of years to perfect, are in danger when any species population is decimating. The balancing natural processes like pollination are crucial to the survival of the ecosystem and human activity threatens the same. Another example is the destruction of coral reefs in the various oceans, which support the rich marine life. What are the steps that can be taken to preserve the biodiversity of our Planet?
  11. Deforestation: Our forests are natural sinks of carbon dioxide and produce fresh oxygen as well as helps in regulating temperature and rainfall. At present forests cover 30% of the land but every year tree cover is lost amounting to the country of Panama due to growing population demand for more food, shelter and cloth. Deforestation simply means clearing of green cover and make that land available for the rethe residential, industrial or commercial purpose. How to tackle this issue?
  12. Public Health Issues: The current environmental problems pose a lot of risk to the health of humans, and animals. Dirty water is the biggest health risk of the world and poses threat to the quality of life and public health. Runoff to rivers carries along toxins, chemicals and disease-carrying organisms. Pollutants cause respiratory diseases like Asthma and cardiac-vascular problems. High temperatures encourage the spread of infectious diseases like Dengue.
  13. Genetic Engineering: Genetic modification of food using biotechnology is called genetic engineering. Genetic modification of food results in increased toxins and diseases as genes from an allergic plant can transfer to target plant. Genetically modified crops can cause serious environmental problems as an engineered gene may prove toxic to wildlife. Another drawback is that increased use of toxins to make insect resistant plant can cause resultant organisms to become resistant to antibiotics. Is Organic Farming a better alternative to this? How far can positive impact saw?
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

item.title: STREET PLAY
item.dc:creator: ad_ditya98
item.description: NUKKAD NATAK The street play translated in Hindi as “Nukkad Natak”, is an attempt to give students a platform to enact existing or foreseen environmental problems in a way they see fit to make other people aware about it. Register About Event Introduction: Street theatre is a form of theatrical performance and presentation in outdoor […]
item.content:encoded:
NUKKAD NATAK

The street play translated in Hindi as “Nukkad Natak”, is an attempt to give students a platform to enact existing or foreseen environmental problems in a way they see fit to make other people aware about it.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

Street theatre is a form of theatrical performance and presentation in outdoor public spaces without a specific paying audience. Artists with an interest in social activism may choose to stage their work on the street as a means of directly confronting or engaging the public. Promoting environmental awareness is an easy way to become an environmental steward and participate in creating a brighter future for our children.
Street plays allow participants to:
  • Analysing issues deeply, thinking about the cause, effect and solution of it
  • Develop their creative acting skills, expressiveness and coordination
  • Boost their confidence
  • Engage with the community

Theme:

Any current environmental issue can be chosen by the teams to generate sensitivity and make public more aware of the issue and how important it is to take the necessary steps to curb it.

Event Guidelines:

  • Teams should pick a topic by 18th April 2018 and inform the organizers about the topic prior to the day of the event
  • Every team will be given 1 min to prepare and organize starting scene.
  • The time duration of the play will be 7-10min
  • Adhere to the time limit.
  • Props required during the performance must be the responsibility of the participants
  • Any extra material required in the form of placards and slogans will be made by participants
  • The medium of language: a mix of English and Hindi both can be used.

Registration details

  • Participate in TEAMS of 5-8 people each
  • Total no. of teams: 6
  • Class- 7-9th
  • Total no. of participants:48

Judgment Criteria

  • Expression
  • Audience engagement
  • Time limit
  • Creativity in presentation
  • Team coordination
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

It offers a chance for participants to gain substantial experience, adopt innovative techniques, showcase talents, analyze and evaluate outcomes and uncover personal ability. Register About Event Introduction: Rangoli has always played a vital role in […]
item.content:encoded:
Paryavaran ki Rangoli

Rangoli Competitions play an important role in motivating students to perform and outshine in their creative skills. It offers a chance for participants to gain substantial experience, adopt innovative techniques, showcase talents, analyze and evaluate outcomes and uncover personal ability.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

Rangoli has always played a vital role in Indian tradition. It has helped in depicting some of the concerning topics in most innovating ways and initiating a spark in the thought process of the observer.
Rangoli Competitions play an important role in motivating students to perform and outshine in their creative skills. It offers a chance for participants to gain substantial experience, adopt innovative techniques, showcase talents, analyze and evaluate outcomes and uncover personal ability.

Theme:

  • Sustainable development
  • Conservation of Environment
  • Environmental concerns and their solutions
  • Importance of making people aware and focusing on behavioural change in people to endure conservation of the environment

Event Guidelines:

  • Maximum number of members in every team: 4
  • Time allocated to every team: 1.5hr
  • Focus on the solution of the problem being depicted in the rangoli

Registration details

  • Participate in TEAM of maximum 4 people (Can belong to one class/mixed classes)
  • Classes: 7-9th
  • Total registrations: 10

Judgment Criteria

  • Relative Content
  • Clarity
  • Creativity
  • Cleanliness
  • Detailing
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

item.title: ENVIRONMENTAL QUIZ
item.dc:creator: ad_ditya98
item.description: ENVIRONMENTAL QUIZ As the name suggests, this quiz will test the knowledge of our participants about our environment. Register About Event Introduction: A quiz is a form of a game or mind sport, in which the players (as individuals or in teams) attempt to answer questions correctly. It is a game to test your knowledge […]
item.content:encoded:
ENVIRONMENTAL QUIZ

As the name suggests, this quiz will test the knowledge of our participants about our environment.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

A quiz is a form of a game or mind sport, in which the players (as individuals or in teams) attempt to answer questions correctly. It is a game to test your knowledge about a certain subject. A quiz is a brief assessment used in education and similar fields to measure growth in knowledge, abilities and skills. They are usually scored in points.
The quiz allows participants to:
  • Enhance knowledge regarding the topic
  • Be up-to-date about current issues
  • Think and answer quickly
  • Improve mind, speech and knowledge coordination

Theme:

This quiz is based on the topics related to environment which may include topics related to green energy, rainwater harvesting, energy conservation, renewable energy, recycling, pollution, soil quality, greenhouse effect, climate change, water purification, waste management, etc. and most importantly the steps to be taken at individual level.

Event Guidelines:

  • Only TEAM entries of 2 people
  • Answer in your own turn.
  • The decision of the quiz-master will be final and will not be subjected to any change.
  • No negative points
  • Four rounds in total
  • Equal points for each question
  • If any team doesn’t answer, the question will be passed to any team answers
  • Only 1 chance for a right answer
  • In case of equal points, a tiebreaker round will be conducted
  • No use of electronic devices
  • The format of the questions can be objective, multiple choice, true/false
  • Replacement of a team member is not allowed after registration

Registration details

  • Participate in teams of 2 people each
  • Total 20 teams
  • Class 7-9th
  • Total registrations: 40

Judgment Criteria

  • Fairly based on the scores.
  • In case of a tie (2 or more participants have the same score), a tie-breaker question will be asked.
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

Students will have to engage with their creative sides to put their ideas and convey them through posters. Register About Event Introduction: Poster making is a creative […]
item.content:encoded:
COLORAMA

The poster making competition called “Colorama”, will showcase the creative skills of our participants in the process of learning about ways to care for our mother earth. Students will have to engage with their creative sides to put their ideas and convey them through posters.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

Poster making is a creative tool which can be used to convey our message about environmental issues and the ways we can take care of it to those who are still unaware or even to emphasize the issue. It is important to maintain a recurring process of making people aware of the importance of our environment.
This competition will portray the creative and innovative skills of students along with problem-solving abilities regarding environmental issues.

Theme:

“My vision of a green and clean environment”. Slogans should be used.

Event Guidelines:

  • Each student will be given an A3 sized sheet on the venue.
  • Colours and stationery should be brought by the students
  • Drawing boards or exam boards for support can be brought.
  • Time: 1.5 hours
  • Any medium can be used – watercolour, pastels, acrylic or poster colours

Registration details

  • Participate individually
  • Class: 7-9th
  • Total registrations: 30

Judgment Criteria

  • Adhering to the time limit.
  • Creativity
  • Innovative solution through art
  • Presentation
  • Slogan
  • Design aesthetics
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

item.title: GREENOVATE
item.dc:creator: ad_ditya98
item.description: GREENOVATE “Greenovate” phrased by members of our team, aims to create awareness amongst students about the amount of waste generated in this present day and age, while teaching them how this waste can be recycled by creating beautiful crafts. Register About Event Introduction: We are in a world of technology and inventions that have changed […]
item.content:encoded:
GREENOVATE

“Greenovate” phrased by members of our team, aims to create awareness amongst students about the amount of waste generated in this present day and age, while teaching them how this waste can be recycled by creating beautiful crafts.

Register

About Event

Introduction:

We are in a world of technology and inventions that have changed our lifestyles and way of survival. This also means that there is excess consumption which leads to more waste generation, which in turn increases our carbon footprint on the earth.  

This event is to give students a creative platform to make working models or crafts with waste materials. This allows participants to think creatively and innovatively, and also develop an understanding of Reduce, Reuse and Recycle.

Event Guidelines:

  • Each team will get the same set of waste materials at the venue itself and participants can use only those materials
  • Time limit: 1.5 hours

Registration details

  • Participate in TEAMS of 3 students, total no. of 8 teams
  • Class 7-9th
  • Total registrations: 24

Judgment Criteria

  • Creativity
  • Type of model
  • Utilization of resources
  • Adhering to time
  • Overall presentation
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

item.title: DEBATE
item.dc:creator: ad_ditya98
item.description: BATTLE OF WORDS The debate competition namely “Battle of Words” will be an interesting exchange of arguments by our participants regarding current environmental issues. Students will get the opportunity to critically analyze the issue and present their arguments, honing their debating skills. Register About Event This allows participants to: Critically analyze the statement or issue […]
item.content:encoded:
BATTLE OF WORDS

The debate competition namely “Battle of Words” will be an interesting exchange of arguments by our participants regarding current environmental issues. Students will get the opportunity to critically analyze the issue and present their arguments, honing their debating skills.

Register

About Event

This allows participants to:

  • Critically analyze the statement or issue
  • Persuade the audience and judges with relevant arguments
  • Consider different perspectives
  • Engage with opposing views and speak strategically
  • Develop a great sense of poise and confidence
  • Enhance presentational skills and organize their arguments
  • Elucidate their standpoint utilizing rhetorical eloquence.

Event Guidelines:

  • Maximum time for each round: 20 mins
  • FOR and AGAINST team will be picked at random
  • Preparation time of 6 mins per team
  • Introduction speech of 2 mins each team alternatively
  • Counter questions or rebuttal for 3 min each
  • Closing argument of 1 min each

Registration details

  • Participate in TEAM of 3 people
  • Class 6-9th
  • Total registrations: 24
  • Total rounds: 4 (two teams in one round)

Judgment Criteria

  • Content
  • Clarity and fluency
  • Style and vocabulary
  • Strategy and presentation.
  • Time taken

Topics for the debate:

  1. The major cause of increasing global warming is the lack of awareness of people about it.

  2. Organic farming is the best alternative compared to food  produced using chemical fertilizers and pesticides

  3. The practice of slash and burn practised by tribals should be abolished.

  4. Behavioural change is the best route to sustainability.

  5. Humans are the primary cause of climate change.

  6. Construction of hydroelectric dams should be prohibited.

  7. Coastal farming should be banned.

  8. The concept of reducing, reuse and recycle can be incorporated into our daily lives effectively

  9. Limited implementation of environmental laws are resulting in the higher amount of environmental damage

  10. Who produces more CO2 emissions – Developing or Developed countries?
Register

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers

item.title: EXHIBITION
item.dc:creator: ad_ditya98
item.description: EXHIBITION This exhibition will showcase the working models using solar energy and recycled craft items built our students, who have undergone the Green School Green Community Program during the last academic year. About Introduction Teach For Green Exhibition is a platform for students from schools where we run our Green School Green Community program can […]
item.content:encoded:
EXHIBITION

This exhibition will showcase the working models using solar energy and recycled craft items built our students, who have undergone the Green School Green Community Program during the last academic year.

About

Introduction

Teach For Green Exhibition is a platform for students from schools where we run our Green School Green Community program can showcase the models they made during the program. Teach for Green has a vision of to promote the importance of green energy and sustainable practices for a better environment through various activities in the field of training and skill development throughout India.

Competition Guidelines:

  • Students from Teach For Green schools will showcase their models
  • Students will highlight their journey and explain their models
  • Guests and participants will be allowed to stroll through the stalls at allotted time
  • The 3 best and most innovative models will be given prizes

Why Join

To Promote the importance of Green Energy for a sustainable environment.

To bring environmental education (EE) out of the classrooms

To engage students and make it fun for them

To encourage students to think about current environmental problems and possible solutions

To provide a relaxed environment for children to interact and learn from their peers
